description.text:
For a while now, Ive been wishing there was a low profile raspberry pi case that looked good, but couldnt find anything, so I designed this.  I got the idea for this when looking a beaglebone cases and rpi A pibow case.  
It replaces part 05,  6, 7, and 8, so you dont need any of those. It has the GPIO pins broke out also so easy GPIO hacking or electronics fun. There's also vent holes over both the processor and the networking/usb chips since both get pretty hot at times.   
Edit: I kept looking at the plate, and figured since you have access to GPIO pins for electronics, you are probably going to need the camera slot open also, so there's another file, rpi5_cam.stl, it has the camera slot cut out.  
I kept getting friends asking if the case allows for the use of different pi plates like the ones that have arduino and such, so I just posted some more pics here of it mounted with my proto plate attached.

description.text:
Ive been wanting a VESA mount for my rpi/computer monitor, but couldnt print the 100mm spacings due to printer bed being 104mm Y axis, and slicers having issues with them, so I made this. It's just a simple VESA mount, but split in half. Just print 2 of them and they'll go together to make a standard VESA mount. When you bolt the case back together, it'll tighten them both up to the point that they wont move at all.  
So this is a VESA mount for pibow cases, for people who cant print out full size VESA mounts due to printer size.

title: Z-axis Linear Rod and Leadscrew Stabilizer for Geeetech i3 Pro B printer with 8mm acrylic frame

description.text:
In 2015 I purchased a Geeetech i3 Pro B printer kit with 8mm Acrylic frame. Attempts to use this printer as it was originally designed always resulted in very rough vertical walls due to poor mechanical tolerance with the Z-axis threaded rods. This caused significant problems printing any part which required tight tolerances, such as parts with integrated print-in-place hinges. I tried several 'solutions' which I found here on Thingiverse and on other internet sources, including the common parts which attempt to physically decouple the Z-axis threaded rod from the X-assembly; these helped a bit, but did not solve the root-cause of the problem. The parts you find here (the yellow parts in the photos) are what I finally came up with to truly fix the problem.

The XYZ calibration cubes photo above shows the before and after results up-close.

Printer:

Geeetech i3 Pro B printer with 8mm acrylic frame

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Material type, infill density and resolution is up to your personal preference. Personally, I printed mine using ABS plastic and 100% infill to maximize the part strength and allow me to drill holes in it wherever I want to later.

You may want to lightly file all exterior edges when done, for aesthetics and fit. Avoid filing the inside of the printed holes where possible; the fit for the linear rod and 608 bearings should be somewhat tight.

I used a digital caliper (accurate to 0.02mm) to measure the top-most acrylic part on my printer, and then re-created that part in Sketchup (not the best tool for modeling solid 3D objects, but I made it work for me) before modifying it to suit my design. First, I made sure to get accurate key measurements for Linear Rod center to Lead Screw center, both of those centers to the printer frame wall, and both of those centers to the upper mourning screw location, before aligning all other part dimensions relative to those core dimensions. Top and bottom pieces share the same measurements for Linear Rod center to Lead Screw center and to the printer frame wall; that's what makes this design work when used in the printer.

I also designed these parts such that no layer cooling fan is needed during printing (has no significant overhangs or bridges), and can be printed on a printer where each layer may not be exactly aligned with the previous layer and can be off by as much as 0.8mm in the X and Y directions (such as a printer which is currently is currently experiencing Z-axis wobble).

While this design works very well, I would like to change the lower part to better fit on the existing Acrylic motor mount using its existing assembly screw hole locations instead of (or in addition to) drilling new holes in the acrylic frame. Unfortunately I have not been able to find the original Geeetech i3 Pro B 8mm acrylic frame design files to know the precise part dimensions and hole locations, and I really don't want to spend the time disassembling, measuring, and recreating them as I did with the top pieces.

Parts needed:
• These four printed plastic parts.
• Four type 608 miniature ball bearings (8mm ID x 22mm OD x 7mm). This bearing size is commonly used in skateboard wheels and should be readily available from any store that sells or services skateboards.
• Four M3 grub screws (or regular screws approximately 5mm long, or longer - length is not critical)
• Four or more M4 screws. 10-12mm long if threading into the Acrylc frame, or 15mm long if threading into a nut on the other side of the acrylic)

Steps to use:
1] Replace the threaded rod with a proper Lead Screw. Personally, I used an inexpensive 8mm diameter 2-start stainless steel Lead Screw with a 2mm pitch and a 4mm lead (a TR8*4-2P Lead Screw). This change required me to reprogram the Z-axis steps per mm setting in the printer's Marlin firmware.

2] Print these four parts I designed, either individually or in pairs using the included files.

3] Remove the X-assembly, Z-axis rods, and Z-axis flexible couplers from the printer, and replace the top acrylic parts with these new printed ones. Also remove the 40mm fan from the lower left side, if you have one installed (it can be re-installed later, using only 2 screws, if needed)

4] insert the 8mm Linear Rod into the 8mm hole in the newly printed top part, and then run it through the 8mm hole in the newly printed bottom part, and finally ensure the Linear Rod goes into the receiving hole in the unchanged acrylic motor mount. This will be used to align your positioning of the newly printed bottom plastic piece, so make sure it is straight and true.

5] Get a cordless drill, and a drill bit which fits loosely into the holes in the newly printed bottom part (these holes are for M4 screws)

6] With the 8mm Linear Rod now in-place as a secured vertical guide from top-to-bottom, carefully postilion the bottom plastic piece so that it is both flush with the acrylic frame and is pressed down against the acrylic motor mount, then use at least two holes of your choice in the bottom plastic piece as guides to drill new holes into the acrylic frame (using the drill and drill bit from step 5) to use as mounting holes for this part.

7] Now tightly secure the bottom plastic piece in-place against the acrylic frame using M4 screws.

8] Remove the 8mm Linear Rod, position/re-mount the X-assembly, and then replace the Linear Rod ensuring it goes through the linear bearings in the X-assembly.

9] Replace the 5mm to 8mm coupler on to the motor shaft, and press a 608 bearing into the large hole on both the bottom and top plastic pieces and gently secure them with a M3 screw (if needed) to stop gravity from pulling the bearing out of the hole.

10] Slide the 8mm Lead Screw through the top 608 bearing, thread it through the Lead Screw nut in the X-assembly, slide it through the lower 608 bearing, and secure it into the coupler on the motor shaft.

The 8mm Linear Rod and the 8mm Lead Screw are now secured at both top and bottom in such a way that they will remain parallel with each other, preventing z-axis wobble.

title: GoPro 3 Snap Lock Mount + CCD Board Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a snaplock Gopro 3 mount combined with CCD Camera mount.  
Snap lock mount is a breeze to remove the the gopro yet very securely holds the gopro in place , i have tested it several times on my own quad and im glad to get rid of nuisance straps.   
The CCD camera board will fit all 38x38 cameras so is not snaplock, the board must be glued/screwed in place.  
if your new to FPV and wondering why you need 2 cameras, many have found a good ccd camera will provide superior live analogue video feed out than a gopro3 and allows gopro to record on the best settings without affecting the live feed screen ratio & lag.

So unfortunately you're going to need full supports, but if your printer is calibrated they will remove nicely from this model.  
i have tried a few designs some with clips on front and back and found this design with two rear clips and a front body support works the best.  
once again this if for the Gopro3, I have tested this using ABS and not PLA, i should imagine it should work just fine with PLA since the clips do not require to bend by any great amount.  
any questions/remarks please leave a comment.

title: Zip Tie Type Bearing Holders For Reprap Pro Huxley

description.text:
I had a problem with the push fit type bearing holders in the stock Reprappro Huxley breaking every time (3 times) I tried to insert them. In truth the problem most likley lies in one of the following things 1) me being clumsy
2) not properly deburing the inside face
3) More than likely my slicing settings where no correct ( I have since found setting a fixed extrusion width ratio in Slic3r to have improved its output no end) But for all you other clumsy fellows I went down the route of modifying the original parts to be shorter and accommodate zip ties on the holders. Use a small dab of super glue and zip tie the LM6UU down. I found the X carriage to be just as easily broken but a dab of super glue will be more than enough on this part. Please note I modified the STEP models from GITHUB using 123d but found the floating bearing holder to be a slightly different shape (older?) to the stl one in the zip file on thingyverse. This shouldent make to much difference though as all the hole centres are the same

These are drop in replacements, just add zip ties ans a spot of superglue.
If you want the source files there are in the attached zip file.

comments.text: This is a great improvement friend.  I will be printing this today!  I upgraded to strong bed springs and the the springs can actually push the politic part off of the bearing!  I was about to drill my board to make a mole for a zip tie!

title: Pocket Soldering Iron Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For my toolbox I needed a light but temperature-controllable soldering iron. On recommendation of a friend I bought a Mustool MT223. In addition to the soldering bob you get five soldering tips. On the road I do not need as many tips but a stand as well as a cleaning sponge. I could not find a stand that corresponds to my ideas. So I designed a foldable stand with place for three soldering tips and a sponge.

After the print, I had to file the pins of the stand round to get these into the recesses of the base. As a splint for the hinge I used 1mm copper wire.

For opening the soldering iron stand press at the front side with the thumb to the base and from the back side with the middle finger against the top - now you can raise the top without problems.

description.text:
I wanted to research this artifact because it was used by the best general during the Civil War because he won the battles which were the turning points of the war. An artifact that he used a lot to survey the battlefield from a distance was his very own field glasses. Only high ranking military soldiers can use the field glasses and this artifact represents the field glasses that used in the Siege of Vicksburg.

Mystery Artifact Created By:
Andre Aghmiuni

Clues...
This object was used by a general during the civil war.
The date on the object represents the large battle that occurred during the civil war.
The object represents a US president that took office shortly after the civil war.

Can you tell...
Which civil war general is represented here?
Which civil war battle is represented with date on the field glasses?
Which US president is represented here?

The Object:
Field glasses which are used to see things from a long distance clearly (binoculars).

Details about the Object:
The object can be found in the The National Museum Of American History where it states that the item was used by Ulysses S. Grant during his time as general in the Civil War.

President:
Ulysses S. Grant, Served 1869-1877, Republican Party

Contribution/ "The Act" & Presidential Role:
His role as president was the commander in chief of the union army which became victorious later in the future in the civil war.

Impact on America/ Significance:
It is important to american history because there would abolish slaves and encourage civil rights for African-Americans later in the future. I chose Ulysses S. Grant because he was the best general in the United States during his time, I enjoy history on different wars and this president was significant to me.

Works Cited:
Simon, J. Y. (2013, August 20). Ulysses S. Grant. Retrieved March 2, 2017, from https://www.britannica.com/biography/Ulysses-S-Grant

S. (n.d.). Ulysses S. Grant's Field Glasses [These field glasses belonged to General Ulysses S. Grant, and were probably used during the Civil War. The objective lenses are 55mm diameter and give a good image. The length is 160 mm (closed). The cloth covered barrels are flared slightly at the eye end; the outer 55 mm are cylindrical.]. Retrieved March 2, 2017, from http://americanhistory.si.edu/collections/search/object/nmah_1301392

To learn more you can follow the link below on the The National Museum of American History which will offer more information on the artifact and the president.
http://americanhistory.si.edu/collections/search/object/nmah_1301392

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Manual Leveling Blocks

description.text:
Due to auto leveling not being a good enough substitute for manual leveling, some Printrbot owners (including me) have switched to manual leveling.

After converting my printer I noticed that the belt was not perfectly straight and was pulling the bed down. These STLs fix this. Simply replace your stock Delrin blocks with these printed ones and pull the belt through the slots. I secured the belt with zip ties.

remixed_from.author: Tripnutz
remixed_from.title: MY FAV PI ( raspberry pi 2/3 case )

description.text:
I really like the look of this case, and wanted to use it for my OctoPi servers. I remixed and added a small hole for the power/read/write LED's for both Pi2 and 3. Added an arm and mount for the Logitech C170.

An M4x30 screw, 2 washers 2 small o-rings and a nylock nut. are required to allow the camera mount to swivel. a m3x50 to attach the C170 cam to the printed mount.

O-rings could be optional but allow for a good friction fit.

To remove the OEM mount from the C170 use a small phillips head screw driver to undo the 2 screws holding the back of the case on. undo the 2 screws holding the PCB in the case behind the PCB is a set screw holding the Pin for the OEM mount. remove the scew and reassemble. You will then be able to remove the Pin from the mount holding it to the cam.

The base of the case should be a snap fit But I found either glueing or FrictionWelding was necessary to attach it securely.

Some adhesive rubber Bump-ons attached to the bottom finish the project giving the OctoPi server a non-slip footing

description.text:
A simple set of filament reel rollers small enough to fit in your pocket, but big enough to do the job. OpenSCAD was used to model the reel roller, and the design drivers are: Use the least amount of non printable hardware as possible.
Easy to set up and put away, as working space is limited.
Small enough to drop in a box for storage and transportation.
To fit any size spool.
All the parts available on Ebay.

To make a pair of reel rollers you need to print four sides, two per unit.
Full prject details here http://airtripper.com/313/pocket-reel-roller/ Parts List 8 x 608 ZZ [8 x 22 x 7] Roller Skate Ball Bearings. Very cheap off Ebay. 8 x M3 x 30mm Hex Head Screws. Ebay. 16 x M3 washers. Ebay. 8 x M3 Nuts. Ebay. 3D Printer Filament. Tools Required 3D Printer. Hex Key to Fit Screw Heads. Pliers or Spanner of some type. 3MM drill bit to clean out the screw holes in the printed parts.

comments.text: Are we not makers? :) Make your own pegs to assemble this project. I designed these 3mm X 25mm pegs for this project. When you separate the pegs from the brim, don't clean them up too much. A little imperfection will give them a snug fit. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1wnvH2HlKl6-3mm-x-25mm-pegs

remixed_from.title: E3Dv6 Bowden X-carriage mount v2 for Prusa i3

title: E3Dv6 Bowden X-carriage mount V2 reversed

description.text:
While the original design is awesome, I've got the problem that im actualy loosing about 25mm of my Anet A8 print bed.

This version is kinda reversed and puts the fan duct on the opposite side in order to get the nozzle more towards the back of the printer. It includes the Tronxy style sensor mount , a 12mm (6mm radius) version and a sensorless one.

I only included rather small holes for the fan duct and mounting it with small wood screws (called "spack schrauben" in germany) since i realy dont wanna fiddle arround with tiny screws and nuts.

Make sure you allign the heatblock and sensor cables like i did on these photos. The longer end of the block schould points towards the back making the cables run the left of the carriage. otherwhise you risk melting your filament cooler.

Things you need

X-CARRIAGE.stl only from Prusa i3 rework kit
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119616/#files

E3D Fand duct
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:547325

Skynet settings

I have been using the config from "A8- 5buttonkeypad- autolevel- stock anet sensor"
and changed these settings to make the Probes level correctly and center the the nozzle.
These settings work perfectly for me, that doesnt mean it would works perfectly for you ;)

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -20
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 10
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -1

#define X_MAX_POS 240
#define X_MIN_POS -20
#define Y_MAX_POS 220
#define Y_MIN_POS -10
#define Z_MAX_POS 240
#define Z_MIN_POS 0

#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 210
#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 220
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 30

title: Just another spoolholder ... with a trick

description.text:
This is a spoolholder which can fit very well in a enclosure.
Most other spool holders were on top of the printer, outside the enclosure, or fixed at the walls of the enclosure. This is not nice in case you have to replace a spool.

So that's why I made this one. The holder can be replaced including the spool, spool can be exchanged and the whole set can be mounted easily in enclosure (or somewhere else).
Really nice for me. Perhaps for you too.

At first the broken scissors handle was not working as there was a broken piece on the side thus the end tip of the scissors would not be hold in place, making the scissors not cut as sharp as possible with the handle moving very easily.

With the new 3D printed part, the thing now works properly as there is no broken bits on the side thus the end tip of the scissors would be held in place. The hole for the end in the handle is actually perfect for the end tip as I carefully measured the end tip and made the dimensions accordingly to the measured data from the end tip of the scissors. Couple of things I could have done better is to make the finger grip hole much bigger with it being a bit thinner as I feel like I wasted excessive filament as I did not need the grip to be has thick as it is. Another thing after printing, I can use sand paper or a power tool to help smooth out the inside and outside as that's how the original handle is suppose to be. Finally with all this done, I can apply a thin layer of glue to make the handle feel smooth and polished like the original.

Printout five of the shutters.
Printout one each of the decorated body that retaining ring and the locking ring. The assembly STL file shows you how these go together, though I have only shown two of the shutters. I used five M3 x 25 mm countersunk screws to hold this together.
My printed version works very smoothly though your clearances may vary.
It is possible to put this together with out the retaining ring the screws will hold the shutters in place by themselves. This shows off the mechanism more.
I intend to add some decoration to the locking ring and the shutters so this is still a work in process.

description.text:
Mount your GoPro Hero4/5 Session onto your HMB-X5(C) frame from Multi-RC at a race-ready 40deg tilt angle. Mounts on with four M3 screws (with two M3 nylocks for the back rearward screws). I use M3x10mm screws into the stand offs at the front and M3x8mm screws into the nylocks at the back. Then use your favorite battery strap to secure the GoPro the mount, should be a snug fit into the ridges. It's extremely secure, highly recommend printing in semi-flexible material like TPU, stands up to severe crashes that way.

Here's a link to the brilliant "Session Skin" pictured on my GoPro: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1643022
Highly recommend to prevent scuffs, I printed mine in orange NinjaFlex.

author: Pyroscooter

description.text:
Could not find a speed holster for my 41 that was scope friendly. So I decided to design my own version. This is just the second revision. It looks pretty good so far. Pin for the barrel stay and the leg strap lower. The top hook to go over the belt. It's getting there. Well version 1 of the Model 41 holster is out of the 3D printer. Had a small issue at the top for some reason but overall a great print. Reinforced the lower and upper to add much needed rigidity and strength. Will have to come up with a Velcro leg strap next. Total print time was 13.50 hours. the overall fit is pretty good and secure. Balances pretty good too. This holster was made with PLA Plastic and should be rigid enough to do the job.

Note: On my machine I had to print vertical so the clip had a height control issue due to support sagging lower than the model creating a height difference. So to solve this I created a more substantial support that should just snap off. If you machine is able to print larger than 370 mm you're fine if you have to print vertical I suggest you use the support file.

Note: I uploaded the G-Code file for the supported Holster. 5 inch barrel

title: GoPro Hero 5 Black Scope / Optic Adapter

description.text:
A while back I bought an adapter for my GoPro Hero 4 to use with my spotting scope. Well, technology moves on, but the company that I bought the adapter from didn't. They never made an adapter for the Hero 5. I even recently bought a mount for my iPhone 7 from them, so it's not like they're just sitting around, happy with what they have. They just haven't done one for the Hero 5. Well, I solved that problem.

I'm not going to mention the company by name. If you have this mount, then you'll know exactly who it is as I haven't seen any other mounts like this. I have included a 41mm optic adapter because I have a different spotting scope that I also want to use this with.

As usual, I've included the Fusion 360 file, so if you want to make your own optic adapter, all you need to do is edit the very first sketch and change the diameter of the center circle to the diameter you need.

I've also added two different versions of the GoPro mount, one that needs supports and one that doesn't. I didn't like the look of the supported model, so I designed one that didn't need supports, but it still works fine.

title: 30mm Stepper Bracket Raise for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, and Maker Select
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After installing AzzA's Z Brace http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948 and Z extension brackets http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1444979 I had the idea to increase usable Z axis even more.
At first I planned rotating the X-axis brackets around but then decided to just lift the stepper motors up.

I printed the parts with 0.2 layer height, 0.8 walls and 60% infill.
Insert rivet nuts before mounting (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00X74FNVW/).
Regular nuts should work as well.
I need to find a shorter rivet nut for the screw behind the stepper motor. Currently I left that one out.
You'll need some extra M3x20 and M4x20 screws as well.

Install:

  • first install AzzA's Z Brace and Z extensions.
  • start on one side first, raise the upper bracket holding the rod up "one notch". Use nuts or lock nuts for the lower 2 bolts.
  • raise the extruder up about 100mm
  • disconnect stepper cable
  • remove 5 bolts from front of frame
  • turn the printer on its side
  • give both stepper motor cables some extra slack
  • remove the 2 bolts connecting the bracket to the y-frame
  • turn the threaded rod to allow the stepper bracket to move up in the frame without twisting the x rods. Make sure the z-rod stays in the upper bracket.
  • screw the stepper motor to the frame (upper 2 holes on frame now line up with lower 2 holes on bracket)
  • insert the printed part and connect top screw with stepper mount, then 2 lower screws to y-frame
  • insert an M3x20 screw to connect the cross brace with the printed part (it helps to tap the hole first)
  • repeat on other side
  • don't forget to connect the stepper motor cables again
  • align the x-axis using http://www.thingiverse.com/make:289720
  • blue print the setup https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XaroNfMVE4M
  • change the "z max length" value in the EEPROM from 180mm to 210mm (I used Octoprint with EEPROM Repetier Editor Plugin)
  • carefully raise the x-axis to the top and check for clearance
  • if you have a Cobra fan it might now hit the stepper bracket (mine did). Once I add a glass bed it might clear it. Otherwise tape a bit of plastic to the x-axis bracket so the x-axis end stop microswitch will engage sooner (verify max travel to the other side)
  • print something tall ;-)

comments.text: Hi, How successful were you in installing this? do you think it is worth it to install this modification?
comments.author: plloppii

comments.text: I have it installed on one printer and it works for me (but might need tinkering). However, I rarely use it since I print tall objects on my new Creality CR-10 (400mm tall) ;-)

title: Sculptr Ninja Top Frame for GT2 Pulley

description.text:
I didn't like the pulleys suggested and preferred to use actual GT2 pulleys. I made the slots bigger and all the way through the frame to accommodate a GT2 pulley and increased the bolt hole to 5mm. Since i am using hollow aluminum tubes for me 175mm cross bars, I also modified the parts with a wire pass through, so that the switch wires can run inside the tubes to the back of the Z frame. The two normal tops have a channel from the switch to into the tube, and the z-axis top has a channel straight back from the inside of the tubes. I didn't make a spool holder version, I don't believe a spool should hang on this frame.

You will need:
3 x GT2 pulleys with 5mm bearing bore
3 x 5x30mm screws

Remixed frame tops from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1444028.

author: faststorm

description.text:
!!ASSEMBLY REQUIRED!!

I wanted a Genji short sword and nobody has one so I made one!

It's loosely based on Genji's washizaki or short sword from Overwatch.

It's scaled to about 17 inches long but the real sword size would be about 25 inches or so. That didn't fit on my printer so it's scaled down. Just a note if anyone wants it to be cosplay accurate.

comments.text: the hilt is a little on the thin side but still good would be better if the blade had a longer tang for a more secure connection to the hilt
